name: Plovdiv
fun_fact: Fun fact: Plovdiv is the oldest continuously inhabited city in Europe, dating back 8,000 yearsâ€”older than Rome, Athens, and Constantinople! Built on seven hills with over 200 archaeological sites, the city reveals history layered on top of itself: Bulgarian Revival houses hover over medieval gates built on Roman foundations. The Ancient Roman Theatre (2nd century AD) is one of the best-preserved in the world and still hosts concerts today. Plovdiv was named European Capital of Culture in 2019.

hero_dishes.name: Shopska Salad
hero_dishes.description: Fresh salad of cucumbers, tomatoes, onion, and grated Bulgarian white cheeseâ€”the first item on almost every Bulgarian restaurant menu
hero_dishes.origin_story: The most important ingredient is the Bulgarian white cheese (sirene), which locals say doesn't taste like this anywhere else in the world. This salad represents Bulgarian pride in their dairy products and fresh vegetables.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Literally every Bulgarian restaurant; Rahat Tepe, Hebros Restaurant, Aylyakria Gastro Bar

hero_dishes.name: Gyuvetche
hero_dishes.description: Spicy stew of beef or pork, mushrooms, onions, peppers, and potatoes prepared in a special clay pot passed down through families, topped with grated cheese and a baked egg
hero_dishes.origin_story: The clay pot (gyuvech) is often a family heirloom, giving each preparation its unique character. This dish showcases Bulgarian love for paprika and hearty one-pot meals. The combination of stewed meat, vegetables, and baked egg creates layers of flavor.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Bulgarian restaurants, especially those specializing in clay pot cooking; Rahat Tepe

hero_dishes.name: Shkembe Chorba (Tripe Soup)
hero_dishes.description: Emblematic Bulgarian soup that's surprisingly delicious despite the tripeâ€”don't give up on it because of the ingredients!
hero_dishes.origin_story: This soup represents Bulgarian comfort food and is often eaten as a hangover cure or late-night meal. It's traditionally flavored with garlic and vinegar, sometimes with milk added for creaminess.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional taverns, late-night eateries, local Bulgarian restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Banitsa
hero_dishes.description: Delicious pastry with layers of filo dough filled with cheese, spinach, or pumpkinâ€”great for breakfast or a snack
hero_dishes.origin_story: Banitsa is quintessentially Bulgarian, eaten for breakfast or as a quick snack. The cheese version uses the famous Bulgarian sirene. It's often paired with boza (fermented drink) for a traditional Bulgarian breakfast.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Bakeries everywhere, breakfast cafÃ©s, street vendors; best eaten fresh and hot in the morning

hero_dishes.name: Moussaka (Bulgarian-style)
hero_dishes.description: Layers of minced meat, potatoes, and eggplant baked with a creamy yogurt toppingâ€”different from Greek moussaka
hero_dishes.origin_story: Bulgarian moussaka reflects the Balkan Peninsula's shared culinary heritage with Greece and Turkey, but uses Bulgarian yogurt for the topping instead of bÃ©chamel sauce. Each Balkan country has its own variation.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Hebros Restaurant (modern take), traditional Bulgarian restaurants, home-style eateries

signature_drinks.name: Rakia
signature_drinks.description: Bulgaria's national drinkâ€”a strong fruit brandy with at least 40% alcohol (homemade versions 50%+), made from grapes, apples, plums, pears, or apricots
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Popularly served as an aperitif with Shopska salad, cured meats, and local cheeses at the start of meals. Enjoyed cold in summer, but during winter Bulgarians drink it hot with honey and/or black pepper. Associated with celebrations like Christmas and New Year, serving as a symbol of hospitality and warmth. Famous variations include grape rakia, plum rakia (slivovitz), and apricot rakia.

signature_drinks.name: Boza
signature_drinks.description: Fermented breakfast beverage made from wheat or millet flour, water, sugar, and yeastâ€”very sweet and thick with creamy texture (contains up to 1% alcohol)
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Consumed at breakfast, often enjoyed with banitsa for a traditional Bulgarian morning meal. It has origins in Central Asia and has been popular in the Balkans for centuries. The sweet, slightly tangy flavor is an acquired taste but beloved by locals.

signature_drinks.name: Ayran
signature_drinks.description: Traditional beverage made of fermented milk (cow, sheep, or goat) mixed with mineral water and saltâ€”tart and refreshing
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served cold as a thirst-quencher during hot summer days. Commonly served with meals. Has probiotics and minerals providing health benefits. Said to have originated in Persia as a way to preserve yogurt with salt. Popular beyond Bulgaria throughout the Balkans.

food_culture_notes: Bulgarian, Greek, and Turkish cuisines share many similarities due to Balkan geography
Bulgaria was under Ottoman domination for almost 500 years, influencing the food
Bulgarian white cheese (sirene) and yogurt are sources of national pride
Plovdiv has the oldest Bulgarian brewery (Kamenitza) and growing microbrewery scene
Meals often start with rakia and Shopska salad
Traditional dishes use lots of paprika and yogurt/sour cream
Hebros Restaurant was named Restaurant of the Year by Bacchus Magazine (2003, 2016)
Clay pot cooking (gyuvetche) is a traditional family method
